Literature Review: The study of oceanic circulation, particularly between the Arctic and Subpolar North Atlantic Oceans, has been significantly advanced through the use of nuclear reprocessing tracers. These tracers, primarily anthropogenic radionuclides released from European nuclear fuel reprocessing plants, have provided invaluable insights into water circulation, mixing, ventilation, and deep-water formation processes. Early research focused on the use of 137Cs as a tracer, which offered some of the first significant insights into the circulation patterns of the Arctic Ocean (Smith et al., 1998). However, the advent of accelerator mass spectrometry has enabled the measurement of more conservative, long-lived radionuclides such as 129I and 236U, which have since become pivotal in tracing oceanic pathways and understanding the connectivity between these critical oceanic regions (Aarkrog et al., 1999). Recent studies have leveraged these advanced tracers, supported by sophisticated modeling efforts such as the North Atlantic–Arctic Ocean–Sea Ice Model (NAOSIM), to provide a detailed inventory of transport data. These data are crucial for understanding the global thermohaline circulation and its implications for climate (Karcher et al., 2012). The use of transit time distributions has further refined these studies by more precisely accommodating the effects of mixing, thereby enhancing our understanding of the temporal aspects of tracer transport (Waugh et al., 2003). The integration of tracer data with oceanographic models has also facilitated the identification of key pathways and mechanisms of water mass exchange between the Arctic and North Atlantic Oceans, highlighting the role of the Nordic Seas as a critical conduit for these exchanges (Rudels et al., 2005). Moreover, the application of 129I and 236U tracers has shed light on the processes of deep-water formation in the North Atlantic, which are essential components of the global ocean conveyor belt (Orre et al., 2010). The insights gained from these tracer studies have not only advanced our understanding of oceanic circulation but have also underscored the importance of the Arctic and North Atlantic Oceans in the global climate system. As such, continued research in this area, particularly with the development of new tracer techniques and modeling approaches, remains vital for predicting future climate changes and their impacts on oceanic and atmospheric dynamics (Dahlgaard et al., 2004).
